pageContext.desc: Children's school compositions and other writings by the Everetts, a Welsh family of American missionaries, writers, and pioneers.

pages.transcription:
Juniors Unclear
Full many a year has rolled its moments on -
Examinations, too, have come and gone -
And juniors without end have stood the test,
And to the Middle [underlined] sank, have bravely pressed
But yet in all these swiftly passing years
No Junior [underlined] paper ever yet appears.
"Your powers that be" now issue their demands
Which claims a paper from reluctant hands.
Our offrings simple, yet with <right good> earnest will
we're toiling up the steep and rugged hill
And when we're higher, then [underlined] we hope to claim
A greater [underlined] postion of the scholars fame.

Ay
We are a strange fraternity, two and yet but one.
As two persons, one is the captain of a mighty land whose
authority is limited by no superior; the other is not now
in any public office, still little business of importance is
ever transacted without his aid. When together we become
an individual whose power is felt and acknowledged
by all, tiny dwarf as we are among our brethern. The
freshness of our youth is still undeminished after having
witnessed many generations use? and pass away. We gave
authority to the mild laws of our country and at the 
same time commanded the cruel wishes of tyrants to be
executed. By acquiting the innocent we have carried
gladness and rejoicing to many a mourning family,
and often we have awarded just penalty to the guilty. Our
name is so extensively known that frequently when
merely spoken it has restored freedom to the trembling
captive or granted pardon to the condemned man. It
is a simple name and when preceeded by other letters
is? greatly changed. Place b before it and a garland
of its branches was one of the highest honors a Greecian
youth could win. Or it becomes a bart of the sea whose
waters more bold than its fellows advances farther into
the entraces? of the land. Let d proceed it and all the
gold of California could not purchase it, and when once

lost, however great and unvearied exertions we may
make, it can never be regained. When f [pr]oceeds it, it
is a little being who opens the petals of the blushing
rose, soothes the murmuring ill, and guids? the hand of
the skillful artist. When it follows g we quickly imagine
a lovely creature arrayed in fantastic dress, a sleeping
babe in ermine. Should ha be placed before it we
have, that to which we are indebted for our delightful
sleighrides. <J transforms it to> Put j before it and my
name is revered by statesmen and patriots, and my attire
is admired by giddy youth and laughing maids. When
preceeded by l it describes the freaks of the wild and
stormy hurricane. M changes it to a delightful season, a 
bright harbinger of coming beauty. Let n preceed our
name and its character is completely changed, what was
the true friend of the culprit now blasts his last
hopes. Place p before it and it becomes the tribute
which Jenny [unknown letter]ind, the goddess of music, receives from 
"admiring thousands, Prefix r to my name and it brightens
the eye of the invalid, or cheers the heart of the student.
Let s be put before it and it is what eminent physicians
say great talkers will have sooner or later. If w preceeds
it it becomes what adventuress have often eagerly sought
amid the wilds of the Rocky Mountains.
Addie.
Mrs Everett

Sketches by the Wayside.
I feel sad and lonely to-night, like
shrinking away from human society, and
seeking the soothing companionship of
nature. How I should like to take a quiet
stroll in the fields, where birds are wont
to sing merry songs to their floral auditors,
the lovely blossoms of the ground. But
as it is too late and cold to admit of my
ramble, and wintry wind and snow have
long ago driven birds and flowers to warmer
regions, I must remain by the fire, consoling
myself with reminicences of 
past wanderings. ___ One time I remember
vividly, I was accompaning my Father
on a journey to Webster Hill. We rode over
rough roads and smooth -- past level,
fresh-looking meadows, and high, rugged 
hills. At one time, almost holding our breath 
with delight, as we gazed upon some singularly
beautiful landscape, portions of
which, the fleeting clouds o'erhead partly
absevred from the suns rays, causing
the light and shadesweetly to blend, -
again gleefully laughing in ur hears.

A leaf from my Album -
To Ellen,
Does they pleasure-cup o'erflow?
Hast thou jays above, below?
Lift to heaven thine eyes in prayer
Thank thy God for all his <pray> care.
The leaf is turned; and is thy heart
Pierced with sorrow's cruel dart?
Drop upon thy knees in prayer. ----
God in mercy sent it there.
Though thy heart with joy be light
Though tis dark with sorrow's night
O still how in earnest prayer:
God will bless and help thee there.
And when death at last shall come
Heaven will be thy happy home.
For thy God who caught thee prayer
Answering will take thee there.

May your pathway, dear Nellie, through
this dreary earth be radiant with light from
above, — may it be cheered with the love and
sympathy of kind earthly friends, and
may you ever feel the presence, and enjoy
the reconciled smile of the best friend
man ever knew — your Saviour and your
God. — Then when life's bewildering journey
is well nigh over — when your trembling
feet shall press the sodd? of the dark "valley
of the shadow of death", and you shall inhale
the sickly perfume of the pale flowers
that blossom there. O, may your longing
gaze be directed to that lovely being who
hath said — "I am the rose of Sharon, and
the lily of the valleys." And when you 
cease to live on earth, may you have "an
abundant entrance into the joy of
your Lord, and spend a blissful eternity
in that bright and happy land, where "sorrow
and sighing shall flee away" and 
where sin can find no entrance.
cease to 
cease to live on earth, may you have

To Miss Ellen,
A place of refuge in his arms,
from lifes rude storms and deaths alarms
A shelter 'neath his shadowing wing.—
His guiding care in everything;—
These gifts, so precious, pure and free
My gentle friend, I crave for thee.
To Ellen,
Heaven bless you Ellen, and 
make you what the world needs, a 
true, whole-hearted, noble woman—
or, as Wordsworth has it
"A perfect woman, nobly planned
To warm, to comfort, and command.

at the ludricous gestures and half-caught
speeches of a party of school=boys at play,
or watching with lively interest the industrious
little woodpecker, whose long beak
laboured as perseveringly on the bark of
an old tree, as if beneath it were hidden
precious hearts.
Decending a slope of a hill we
found ourselves near a small town,
and on our right there stood a neat white
church, with green blinds and a modest-
looking steeple, pointing derarily but cheerfully 
upward. Just as we were passing
by, a snow-white dove lit upon its
summit, seemingly an embodiment of purity
and holiness, sent from heaven to show
that God had chosen that little spot as
his temple, over which he would delight
to watch, and where he would often send
his Holy Spirit.— Father looked up to 
the dove and playfully said - "Little birdie
weren't you afraid of falling from up there"
But the "little birdie" appeared to feel
perfectly secure, and looked wonderingly

dawn on us, as if it wished to say. I am a resident of the skies, [and know not what fear is [crossed out]] I find my chief delight in soaring to greater heights than these, and never think of falling. Leaving the pretty alone to enjoy its elevated position we prove? unclear, and soon entered one of the most romantic forrests I ever beheld. The thick branches of the trees shut out every distant view, so that we almost fancied we were imprisoned there. And an imposing looking prison it was, not however, devoid of {{loadiness?]]. The road lay near a lively river, on either side of which arose huge piles of rock and regular shelves of slate=stone, or rather had arisen, long ago, probably on that ancient day. When God created the Heaven and the earth, and they looked as though they would remain there with the earth itself would fade away. The stream followed at times with a subdued and murmuring sound, calling up strange and tender emotions, then dashed wildly and violently onward, commanding silence

on everything around, so that it might speak, and indeed that noble river may have uttered many beautiful and convincing truths, which would have been of abun-dant use to me if I were only enough skilled in water language to com-prehend their import?. [[Unclear}}.

A few years ago, a cherished wish was gratified and I was fascinated to visit New England.I had often dreamed of this, usually fancying myself mistress of a New England school house, which thought, some story early read had invested with a charm. But, contrary to my dreaming I went merely as a student to a little village near the center of New Hamp-shire, six miles distant from any railway station. Here, new fears? were around me, I saw new customs, had new paths, new fears and hopes, and fears alternate, vexed my burdened heart, while every fresh perplexity, and many a fancied trial made it unclear earnest longing towards my distant home. But pleasure soon joined hand with sadness, and I was cheered. unclear scenery, so wild

beautiful, not only soothed each troubled thought but caused a rush of joyous feeling, irresistable and free! Yes, freedom was the lesson my gladdened heart took home, and truly if anywhere the mind may feel unfettered, it is among those noble mountains of the old "Granite State", where the dazzling Summer sun shines with such brightness, and Winter with provoking coolness blows. His fiercest gale, and unburdens his biggest cloud of snow. The village was in keeping with the scenery, the buildings being thrown, as if by chance, right amongst the hills and trees and rocks, and rumbling waters. Some of the houses looked as if they had just been skating down hill, and had just stepped aside to rest awhile. There was a charming re-treat near by, which bore the suggestive name of "Love's unclear". I never ventured within its limits, but heard unclear stories about those whose wandering beguiled them thither.

They became strongly bewildered, so the rumor ran, and talked such talk as sane mor-talk could make nothing of, and for months after the infatuated ones scarcely recognized their old friends or the world in which they lived, but, as in a trance, saw no one save some fairy angel being, to whom they were ever whispering words of undying love. The place was truly beautiful, guarded on one side by shadowy oaks and whispering pines, and on the other by a narrow rivulet which lay between it and the road. Often have I stood by the roadside, watching the silent moving of the shadows, that stretched downward from the waters further bank, and thought them more lovely in their quiet beauty than the waving branches from which they caught their form. I regarded the stream with special interest for I had seen its mother river, the unclear and had heard her with low voice bemoaning the loss of her merry daughter. From its indian name, I knew that it had wandered here

long ago, and thought perhaps some govng chief, standing with his bride in the enchanted region of Loves Grotter, first called it, Pemmegewasset. I loved the name for its pretty sounding, but I loved it more for carrying back my thoughts, where there was little to engage them beside fancy's lively painting.

"While I was musing the fire burned." As first only a feeble smoke rose from the few coals? among the sticks, then a small, flickering blaze is sent forth by a slender chip?. Soon another caught the flame and bolder and higher they rose together. Now all is in a blaze and the bright light ascends higher and higher till it fills the whole place. No longer struggling amid the cold wood the fire freely moves upward through every crevice. There was yet another fire that burned while I thus mused. The little spark I had placed in the midst of my dormant thoughts began to kindle. First a little insignif-icant thought {began to kindle[crossed out]} glowed, then larger and more important ideas reddened and a gentle flame ascend-ed. Now deeper and bolder thought catch the flame till every chamber of my brain is enlightened and the fire burns through my whole soul. I see around me? many fires burning while men stand by moaning. Some are clear and holy fires and convince? approvingly replenishes them; others are dark unrighteous flames and the evil unclear watch

over and pile on the fuel. There a mother is mourning over the fire that has gathered around her only daughter. She was a beautiful girl and eagerly sought the joys of life. Her companions were voteries of pleasure and when wearied with their mirth she kindled her wasted energies with the sickly fire of some overwrought imagination. Her mother saw the evil tending of this course but mistaken love held back the warning till too late. for while she hesitated consumation? had kindled in the bones of the maiden. In vain now must the physician strive to quench this fire, his skill cannot reach it, the girl must die. At a little distance is another person so completely enveloped in flames that I can scarcely? see him He was once a happy man but in an evil hour a spark of dislike fell among his affections. One afternoon he wished the woe of his neighbor's carriage but it hug? give to turn?. Vexed by the disappointment his evil genius ventured to suggest that his neighbor knew he wanted and had therefore chosen that day to go to the city. As he unclear this over this he remembered that not long since this very neighbor's cattle had broken into his grain and now he doubted not that their owner had himself turned them into his? field, for why should thy have broken over that night and not before. Thus one little circumstance

after another was magnified till his friend, all unconscious, had changed into a bitter enemy. He resolved to be avenged and while he plotted the scheme the fire of hatred burned hotter and stronger till it seemed that all his better nature was consumed and he was ready for any dreadful deed. I dared not lurk any longer but quickly turned my eye in another direction. Here I saw another man writing and groaning in the midst of a burning fire. He was a youth of a fine talent and superior education, but he had learned to love the wine cup. At first he simply tasted a little when in company, lest he should be thought singular. Each time, however he took a little more for it was becoming pleasing and he desired it more and more frequently. In order to gratify this new appetite, he visited saloons and was even now and then seen at the bar room?. One day in company with a comrade he drank to exess? and become intoxicated. This aroused him to a sense of his danger and determined to reform; but not now, he felt so unclear he would take a little once more. The next day he found it no easier to let it alone, nor the next, nor the next yet he would do it sometime. But while this he mused the fire burned, and now he is a confirmed drunkard.

The cherries are ripe, the cherries are ripe,
Oh, give the baby one;
The cherries are ripe, the cherries are ripe,
The baby must have none.
Babies are too young to choose,
Cherries are too sour to use
But, bye and bye, made in a pie,
No one will then refuse
Up in a tree, a robin I see,
Picking them one by one,
Shaking his bill, taking his fill,
As down in his throat they run.

Robins need no cherry pie,
Quick they eat, and off they fly,
My little child, patient and mild
Surely will not cry.

Sudden bewilderment in conversation, wholly losing trace of the topic. Most apt to unclear when unclear or the system is generally out of order. Has a fixed look. Has seasons of despondency when she thinks no one is so deserving of ill as herself. Is afraid of getting in people's way; studies over every evil act of past life and lives in a state of morbid unclear. Often feels it a sin to eat. When perplexed or irritated is relieved by getting out of sight and making fences. Stretching, widening the mouth throwing forward the chin.

unclear mind is long taxed, will have pain in temples, at hives extreme sensations? to touch, left? temple the worst. Nose cold in winter so that unclear pain will accum on stepping out of doors. After close study most tedious buzzing? across middle of nose, relieved by heavy pressure with the finger. Fatigue and as a symbol? reproofs of conscience both cause indigestion, at times extremely sour vomiting, blistering the lips.
Noisy emetations of wind. Somewhat unclear to constipation Occasional diarrhea from excitement or change of diet. unclear frequently but slowly coler usually normal rather pale unclear the call to urinate is

disregarded shark hypogastric & abdominal pains with feverishness and headache. Menses frequently postponed and scant, very easily cheeked excitement or fatigue. For the last unclear - five? nine? months unclear greenish mucous lenconhea, increased by walking on or excitement, any sudden emotion.
As subject to hysterical attacks when spoken unkindly to, or is startled; circulation is hindered, unclear in arms and axillae, and lower extremeties, when no spasms occur, they feel for hours as if they had been "asleep", when the spasms do finally overcome her, she often shrieks, falls

on the floor or bed, written above: rapidly stomps with her feet, or if unclear, crossed out: kiks throws up her feet and after that other as if kicking sometimes runs backward on tip toe unclear -- &? then falls, stretches mouth & neck throws head backwards Face grows red, estremeties cold. The attacks last but a few moments and are followed by exhaustion She never loses consciousness, always finishes with a cry, which is followed by a profuse discharge of limpid urine.
Has? retroversion, also extreme sensitiveness of as vaginam, making replacement guilt painful. As? is followed however by much improvement in symptoms.

Ida - A Sketch
"Death Loves a shining mark"
Ida, she going the beautifull, and beloved, was the only remaining child of her aged father.  On her was lavished all the cherished hopes, and find love of his affectionate heart.  And deeply and devotingly did she appreciate his tender affection.  Pearce three months had elapsed since she had been called to look upon her Mother for the last time.  Then it was that here naturally light and Berryant heart was crushed with grief.  With a overwhelming beat of anguish she received the last blessing of her Mother.  Ida my darling child said she feably "I am dying" I must leave she my gentle one and my beloved Father.  Oh speak "for so dear Mama" exclaimed she meeting Ida, sharing her self on her kins by the couch of her dying Mother no no more.

must not leave? us, Oh! what will become of poor Ida? My child replied she in a calm and subdued voice, It is my savior? that call and I go unclear my lovely children in this faith? land where parting is unknown and where the weary are as unclear the wicked cease from triumphing? he comforted for ye shall follow him And with a fervent pray to heaven for her blessing to rest unclear its unclear Ida grief subsided at last she was peacefully? calm. But that peace was destined for? it be broken. Aching came over unclear spirit? of Ida. She was no longer heard consoling first some? pleasantly?. Her slip was less firm and elastic and it was unclear than consumption was unclear her to an early grave. Owith what one ageing heart, her father behold this change, But unclear was mother? unclear beheld? with as heavy heart this was Alfred her betrothed
